She estimates that the loan will help her business to grow a little more and increase her merchandise. Her future plan is to continue expanding her inventory and sales.

loans.use: to buy strollers, bathtubs, infants clothing, diapers, etc.

loans.name: Shahla

texts.en:
Shahla is a 42-year-old married woman who has three daughters. Shahla is a very caring mother. Her first goal is to give her children a good life. For that she is working everyday without rest. 

She sells office supplies such as tape, calculators, bulbs, etc. Her profit in this business is 100 AZN monthly, but that is not enough to take care of her children and to buy goods for her store. She is also very worried about giving her daughters a good education, which will be a great contribution to the society.

Now Shahla needs a loan of 1,000 AZN. With this money she plans to bring more supplies to the store and increase her sales. She has already taken three loans from Aqroinvest in the past. Shahla  is very optimistic about this business and she awaits your support.

loans.use: to bring more supplies to the store and increase her sales.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine is married and has four children who all go to school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She resides in her own house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

She has a business of frying edibles like samosa, donuts and chapatti. She has been in this business for two years and works in a shop seven day out of every week. 

She has applied for a loan of 300,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more cooking oil, cow peas, and baking flour.  Her major business challenges include ever increasing prices of cooking oil and seasonality. 

She is aspiring to own a big bakery and also to educate her children up to university.

loans.use: To buy cooking oil, baking flour, cow peas, and bag of charcoal.

loans.name: Eldaniz

texts.en:
Eldaniz is a 33-year–old married man. He has three children. Eldaniz is an IDP (internally displaced person) and lives with his family in the Bilasuvar IDP settlement.  

He raises sheep and sells them for meat. Eldaniz has been doing this business for six years and is a very hardworking person. He puts a lot of effort into this activity, because he wants to support his family without lacking financially.

Eldaniz is keeping a flock of sheep in his own yard. He fattens them and takes their meat to the central bazaar, where butchers and customers purchase this. People use mutton for traditional dishes like kababs, dolmas, pilovs, etc. 

This is going to be his first loan. He requires 2,000 AZN to purchase 15 sheep in order to sell more meat in winter. Eldaniz is optimistic about this loan, because in winter more people consume meat, due to the holidays and increased customers in restaurants.

loans.use: to purchase 15 sheep.

loans.name: Gaspard

texts.en:
Gaspard is 38 years old. He is married and has five children. 

He would like to use a Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase  production. With profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Edgar

texts.en:
Edgar is from Gogaran village in the Lori region. He is 39 years old and lives with his retired parents. 

For the past 20 years, Edgar has been involved in agriculture. He keeps four cows, seven sheep, a pig, and chickens. Near the village where Edgar and his parents live, they own a plot of arable land where wheat, barley, and potato are grown.

As a result of Edgar's hard and tireless work, he is able to sell his gathered harvest, meat, and dairy products to re-sellers and thereby provide for the basic living conditions of his family. Edgar is now asking for a loan of USD $1,500 to purchase fodder for his cattle to provide for them during the winter months. He took a loan from a local financial institution before and because of his family's poor conditions wasn’t able to pay it back on time.  

However, thanks to hard work during recent times, Edgar was able to run his agribusiness in a sustainable way, ensuring that he will be able to cover the monthly payments. So, he has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The second-chance loan program provides loans to people who have a bad credit history and have no access to credit products.

Edgar and his parents hope for the lenders' goodwill and support.

loans.use: to pay for fodder for feeding the livestock

loans.name: Susanna

texts.en:
Susanna is an experienced agronomist from Zadea village in the Vaytos Dzor region. She lives with her husband and 9 year old son. Susanna works in the postal service, and her husband works as a contractual serviceman in the military service. Both of them work hard to be able to earn a living. Their salaries, however, are not enough to cover the daily expenses of the family. 

It has been more than 15 years since Susanna was engaged in cattle breeding, in aviculture (breeding birds), in breeding sheep, and in the cultivation of several fruits (peach, apricot, apple, pear, and walnut). With the help of her husband, she realizes the agricultural products needed in the local market, which is a very important source of their income. 

To continue running her agribusiness in a sustainable way, Susanna needs a loan of USD $2,500 to purchase six sheep and a calf and to make previous credit repayments. She has already taken a loan from a local financial institution before, but unfortunately wasn't able to return it back. However, thanks to the hard work during the recent times, Susanna was able to run her agribusiness in a sustainable way, ensuring that she will be able to cover the monthly payments. So, she has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The second-chance loan program provides loans to people who have a bad credit history and have no access to credit products. Susanna and her family will be thankful to all the lenders for helping them to maintain their agribusiness.

loans.use: to purchase six sheep and a calf and to make previous credit repayments

loans.name: Akua

texts.fr: Revendeuse de produits d'alimentation générale,Akua a pour mari un main-tenancier et mère d'un enfant de 05ans scolarisé. Elle revend ses marchandises dans une boutiques et fait sa toute première demande de prêt pour acheter plus produits afin de répondre aux besoins des clients. Elle souhaite mieux augmenter son stock et assurer l'épanouissement de la famille. Elle a 39ans avec une ancienneté de 03ans dans l'activité.
texts.en: Akua works reselling general food items. She is married with one five-year-old child, who is in school. Her husband is a maintenance technician. She sells her items in a store. She is requesting her first loan to buy additional products to respond to the needs of her customers. She would like to increase her stock and make sure that her family gets ahead in life. She is 39 years old, and has been working at this activity for three years.

loans.use: to buy general food items.

loans.name: Munyaradzi

texts.en:
Munyaradzi is a single woman aged 29 living in Harare, Zimbabwe. 

She volunteers teaching life skills education, leadership and entrepreneurship to young women. She started the business as a fruit vendor in 2012 because she wanted to become economically independent.

She really loves her business and she feels it has the potential to grow. A Kiva loan will assist her in expanding the business by opening a fruit and vegetable stall at the local fruit and vegetable market. This will bring stability to her business. She hopes to provide for her child and put him through school.

loans.use: To open a fruit and vegetable stall.

loans.name: Hagar

texts.en:
Although she has received no prior formal education, Hagar is an entrepreneur. She specializes in running a small grocery store in Asafa (near Elmina). She has been involved in this enterprise for fourteen years. Hagar is married and has five children. Her husband works as a farmer. The proceeds from her business normally go towards helping her husband cover the family’s general expenses and pay their children’s school fees. 

Hagar wants to use her loan to increase her current inventory levels, thus allowing her to sell greater quantities of groceries. In the long term, Hagar plans to reinvest future profits into her business, thus helping her expand and meet the needs of rising customer demands.

loans.use: to increase her current inventory levels, allowing her to sell greater quantities of groceries.

loans.name: Benjamin

texts.en:
Benjamin is single and has one child. After successfully graduating middle school, Benjamin became a farmer in his village of Asafa (near Elmina). He has been actively involved in this business for about twelve years. As the sole breadwinner in the family, Benjamin uses his income to provide for the entire family. 

He will use the loan to purchase increased amounts of fertilizers and other farming supplies, thus aiding him to increase his harvests. With the new profits from his expanded business, Benjamin plans to diversify the type of products that he grows, allowing him to hedge against slow markets.

loans.use: to purchase increased amounts of fertilizers and other farming supplies, thus aiding him to increase his harvests.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is married with four children and all her children go to school. She takes care of additional family members (sister). She has a beauty salon business and has been in this business for one year. She has applied for a loan of 300,000 from MCDT SACCO to buy more boxes of cream relaxers, weaves, shampoo, treatments and braids. She doesn’t have any other income generating activity. 

She works in her shop seven days out of every week and sells on a retail basis. Her major business challenges include seasonality and thieves. She is aspiring of owning a fully stocked beauty salon and also to buy a plot of land and build her own house. She resides in a rented house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy weaves, hair rollers, braids, shampoo and relaxers.

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
This is 32-year-old Hawa. She is married and has three children, ages 14, 11, and 8. She has three additional dependents who live with her for schooling.  

In 2003, Hawa established her shoes, clothing, and textiles business. She began her business just to assist her husband in settling their domestic bills. Her business is located at city center and her main customers are both men and women. Working seven days a week and 11 hours a day, she earns about SLL 900,000 every month from this business. 

Hawa would like a loan in the amount of SLL 5,000,000. Hawa has already received and successfully repaid one loan and now she requires a new loan in order to buy men's slippers, ladies' slippers, and skirts. She hopes that this loan will increase her profit margin. 

In the future, Hawa plans to own a house and to increase her stock level. She gives thanks to Kiva. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy clothing and textiles.

loans.name: Wilmar Andrés

texts.es:
Wilmar es un joven emprendedor de 23 años de edad, que desde muy pequeño se vio involucrado en el campo de la confección, pues sus familiares realizaban esta actividad y a medida que fue creciendo, le enseñaron la labor, comenzó a trabajar en los talleres familiares y luego logró ahorrar el dinero suficiente para comprar sus propias máquinas e independizarse; trabaja con el apoyo de una empleada directa, su jornada es de lunes a sábado de 7:30 am a 6:00 pm o dependiendo del volumen de producción que tengan, pues sus servicios son dirigidos especialmente a terceros.
Con el fin de fortalecer su negocio, solicita el apoyo del crédito para comprar una máquina a dos agujas, con la que podrá optimizar mejor el tiempo de producción, sacando más lotes por día y así aumentar sus ventas y entregar los pedidos de manera oportuna y ágil; lo que dará como resultado un incremento en los ingresos.
Wilmar como todo ser humano tiene sueños, pero él se proyecta para un futuro cercano teniendo un taller de confección mucho más amplio, en el que pueda generar más oportunidades de empleo y además desea sacar confección de línea propia; así mejorará sus finanzas y podrá disfrutar una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Wilmar is a young entrepreneur of 23. He has been involved in the sewing business since he was small as his family members worked in this activity. As he grew he was taught this work and started to work in the family workshops. Later he managed to save enough money to buy his own machines and go out on his own. He works with the help of one direct employee. He works from Monday to Saturday, 7:30 am until 6 pm depending on the volume of production he has. His services are orientated to third parties.

With the goal of strengthening his business Wilmar is requesting a loan to buy a twin stitching sewing machine. With it he can maximize his production, finishing more pieces per day. Therefore Wilmar can increase his sales and  delivery the orders in an expedient and fast manner which will give him more income. 

Wilmar like all human beings has dreams, but he sees the near future as having a much bigger workshop where he can generate more work opportunities. He also wants to produce his own clothing line. This would improve his finances and he would be able to enjoy a higher quality of living.

loans.use: to buy a twin stitching sewing machine.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en: This is 52-year-old Fatmata. She is married and has five children, ages 26, 23, 21, 19 and 16. She has one additional dependent who lives with her: her sales assistant. In 2003, Fatmata established her business selling provisions and drinks. She began her business just to help her husband run their home. Working 7 days a week and 11 hours a day, she earns about 800,000 SLL every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of 4,000,000 SLL. Fatmata has already received and successfully repaid four loans. She now requires a new loan to buy raw eggs (1,250,000 SLL), Irish potatoes (1,250,000 SLL), and drinks (1,500,000 SLL). In the future, Fatmata plans to build a house, to educate her children, and to travel to the holy land of Mecca. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy eggs, potatoes, and drinks

loans.name: Ambrose

texts.en:
This is 45-year-old Ambrose. He is married and has one child, age 8. In 2003, Ambrose established his business selling provisions, drinks, toiletries, water, and recharge cards. He started the business to be self-reliant after dropping out of school. 

His business is located in the outskirts and his main customers are adults. Working 7 days a week and 12 hours a day, he earns about 600,500 SLL every month from this business. He would like a loan in the amount of 3,000,000 SLL. Ambrose requires a loan in order to buy provisions and drinks for his business. 

He hopes that this loan can increase his inventory and expand the business. In the future, Ambrose plans to improve the business and expand the recharge cards trade. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy provisions and drinks

loans.name: Binta

texts.en:
This is 51-year-old Binta. She is a widow and has three children, ages 12, 20, and 22. She has one additional dependent who lives with her to help with the household chores.

In 1994, Binta established her business selling provisions and beverages. She began her business because she wanted to be self-reliant after losing her husband. Her business is located in the outskirts and her main customers are adults. Working 7 days a week and 12 hours a day, she earns about 2,000,000 SLL every month from this business. 

She would like a loan in the amount of 5,000,000 SLL. Binta has already received and successfully repaid six loans. She now requires a new loan in order to buy additional drinks. She hopes that this loan can improve her inventory and increase her profits. In the future, Binta plans to expand the business to wholesale. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy drinks for her business.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is 35 years old. He would like to use this Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase the harvest. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Celestin

texts.en:
Celestin is 46 years old. He is married with one child. He would like to use a Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase the harvest. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en:
Vincent is 45 years old. He is married with four children. He would like to use a Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase the harvest. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Fredisminda

texts.es:
Fredisminda, solicita un nuevo crédito para facilitar la compra de pollo, repollos, lechuga, leña , etc., ya que son insumos necesarios para seguir trabajando en su negocio.
Con el préstamo anterior adquirió lo necesario para que su negocio continúe activo y siga  generando los ingresos que necesita para cubrir los gastos de su hogar, su familia goza de mejor alimentación, salud y vestuario. Todos se encuentran saludables.
texts.en: Fredisminda is requesting a new loan to buy chicken, cabbage, lettuce, firewood, etc., which are items she needs to continue working in her food production and sales business. With her previous loan, she purchased the items she needed to keep her business going and to continue earning income that she needs to pay household expenses and to improve her family’s food, health and clothing. She reports that all of her family is healthy.

loans.use: to buy chicken, cabbage, lettuce, firewood, etc.

loans.name: Tariro

texts.en:
Tariro is a 24-year-old single mother of one child living in rural Zimbabwe. Tariro volunteers as a Camfed Learner Guide at a high school in her district teaching students life skills education as a part of Camfed’s My Better World program. Starting in 2009, Tariro has been running a poultry business where she produces about 125 broiler birds every six weeks and sells them to the local residents in in her community. She would very much like to increase her sales and expand her business.

With a Kiva loan, Tariro will purchase more broiler chicks and chick feed to increase production and boost her sales. Improving her business will improve her life considerably and she will be able to provide for her child and as well as her dependents and put them through school.

loans.use: to purchase more chicks and feed

loans.name: Anahit

texts.en:
Anahit is an experienced farmer from Goris city in the Syuniq region. She lives with her daughter, 4-year-old granddaughter and 2-year-old grandson. She works in a private bakery as a baker. She is the main breadwinner of the family. Her salary, however, is not enough to effectively meet her family's needs. To be able to cover those needs, Anahit is also engaged in breeding livestock (a cow and a pig), in beekeeping and in the cultivation of potatoes. She sells the agricultural products in the local market, which is a very important source of the family's income. Her daughter assists her greatly in everyday activities related to farming. 

Anahit currently needs to make some investments in her agribusiness in order for it to function in a sustained way. She needs a loan of USD 600 to purchase forage (grass and barley) for the livestock. She has already taken a loan from a local financial institution before, but unfortunately wasn't able to pay it back. However, thanks to the hard work during recent times, Anahit was able to run her agribusiness in a sustainable way, ensuring that she will be able to cover the monthly payments. 

So, she has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF International. The second-chance loan program provides loans to people who have a bad credit history and have no access to credit products. Anahit and her family rely on the good will of the lenders and will be thankful to them for helping the family to maintain their agribusiness.

loans.use: to purchase forage (grass and barley) for the livestock.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
This is 54-year-old Ibrahim. He is married and has 5 children, aged 26, 24, 21,18 and 15. In 1982, Ibrahim established his electronics and jewelery business. He began his business to solve his domestic problems. His business is located at the city center and his main customers are both men and women. Working 7 days a week and 11 hours a day, he earns about Le 1,000,000 every month from this business. 

He would like a loan in the amount of Le 5,000,000. Ibrahim has already received and successfully repaid 2 loans, and now requires a new loan in order to buy jewelery (1,000,000 SLL), a 21 inch television (1,500,000 SLL) and music sets - 2,500,000. He hopes that this loan will increase his capital base and hence his profit. In the future, Ibrahim plans to educate his children and to travel to the holy land of Mecca on a pilgrimage. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy electrical goods and jewelry to sell.

loans.name: Seynabou's Group

texts.fr: Créé le 05 Mai 2007 à l’inauguration du banc villageois, ce groupe est composé de femmes qui ont une expérience dans le programme des bancs villageois. Elles sont toutes issues du même quartier et partageant des liens forts de solidarité et d’entre aide. Elles ont comme activité principale le petit commerce. Madame Aminata (debout à l’extrême droite avec une main levée), est l’emprunteuse vedette du groupe. Elle est mariée, est âgée de 28 ans et mère d'un garçon et de deux filles. Elle achète du bois et du charbon de bois, des tissus teintés pour les revendre dans son quartier à un prix plus élevé. Avec son nouveau crédit, elle compte acheter un camion de bois à 200000F CFA , 100000F CFA de charbon de bois et 50000F CFA de tissus. Les bénéfices, elle compte les utiliser pour appuyer son mari dans la scolarisation de ses enfants d’une part et d’autre part à améliorer les conditions de vie de la famille aussi renforcer son épargne dans le banc villageois.
texts.en:
Established on May 5, 2007, at the inauguration of the banc villageois, this group is made up of women who have experience with banc villageois programs. They are all from the same neighborhood and share strong ties of solidarity and mutual assistance. Their primary activity is small business.

Mrs. Aminata (standing at far right with a hand raised [in the photo]) is the group's featured borrower. She is married, 28 years old, and the mother of one boy and two girls. She purchases wood, charcoal, and tinted fabric to resell in her neighborhood for a higher price. With her new loan, Mrs. Aminata plans to purchase a wood truck for 200,000 CFA francs, as well as 100,000 CFA francs of charcoal and 50,000 CFA francs of fabric.

Mrs. Aminata plans to use part of the profits to support her husband in sending their children to school and the rest to improve her family's living conditions as well as to increase her savings with the banc villageois.

loans.use: To sell charcoal and wood.

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Hawa, age 34, established her plastic products business in 2006. She began this venture because she wants to help her husband, who was crippled in an accident while he was engaged in running the home. They have four children, ages six, eight, fifteen, and twenty-two. Hawa's business is located in the city center and her main customers are women. Working seven days a week and 14 hours a day, she earns about Le 1,560,000 every month from this business.

Hawa would like to request a loan in the amount of Le 4,000,000. She has already received and successfully repaid three loans, and her new loan will be utilized to buy additional bathing buckets, food flasks, and plastic plates. She is confident that this loan will allow her to increase her stock and make more profit. 

In the future, Hawa's goal is to be able to support the costs of her children's education. 

She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy bathing buckets, food flasks, and plastic plates.

loans.name: Alpha Bakarr

texts.en:
This is 38-year-old Alpha Bakarr. He is married and has three children aged five, ten and fifteen. In 2009, Alpha Bakarr established his flowers, picture frames, window linings, mats, clocks, Christmas trees, and house decorations business. 

He began his business in order to be self reliant after coming from the village. His business is located in the city center and his main customers are adults. Working seven days a week and 10 hours a day, he earns about Le 1,141,000 every month from this business. 

He would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000. Alpha Bakarr has already received and successfully repaid two loans and now requires a new loan in order to pay for additional Christmas decorations. He hopes that this loan can increase the stock and expand the business. 

In the future, Alpha Bakarr plans to improve the business and expand to a shop. He started the business selling for his brother, and he now owns his own. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to pay for Christmas decorations

loans.name: Sallay

texts.en: This is 40-year-old Sallay.  She is married and has three children aged four, seven and thirteen.  She has one additional dependent, who lives with her to help with the house chores.  In 2003, Sallay established her dry fish business.  She began her business to help her husband with running the home.  Her business is located in the city centre and her main customers are women.  Working seven days a week and ten hours a day, she earns about Le 544,190 every month from this business.  She would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000.  Sallay requires a loan in order to buy fish.  She hopes that this loan will help her to improve the stock and raise the profit.  In the future, Sallay plans to expand the business to imported rice.  She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy fish

loans.name: Aghasi

texts.en:
Aghasi is a farmer from Stepanavan city in the Lori region. He lives with his wife. Aghasi works as a driver in the private sector. He is the main breadwinner of the family. Unfortunately his salary alone is not enough to cover the daily expenses of his family. He is also engaged in agribusiness to be able to take care of his family. 

With the help of his wife he is involved in cattle breeding, in aviculture and in breeding pigs. He sells the agricultural products in the local market, which is an important source of the family's income. As life is getting more expensive with time, Aghasi wants to expand his agribusiness a little bit to more effectively meet his family's needs. To reach that goal, he needs a loan of USD 3,000 to purchase three steers, and to buy some forage for the cattle. 

As this is Aghasi’s first loan, it has been approved within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and SEF. The first-chance loan program provides loans to people who didn’t have access to credit products before because they have no credit history. Aghasi and his wife will be very thankful to the lenders for their good will and support in collecting the needed amount of the loan.

loans.use: to purchase three steers and to buy some forage for them.

loans.name: Hernan

texts.es:
Hernan agradece a los inversionistas por el préstamo y se siente contento por el apoyo brindado,  él continua con la venta de carne de cordero, res, pollo, vacuno y porcino. Ya son varios años que se dedica a  este negocio y le va muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo. 

Hernan sigue perteneciendo al banco comunal “Mamacha Carmen” y esta oportunidad requiere el préstamo para comprar carne de cordero, chancho, pollo, pescado y otros más. Agradece y valora el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas mensuales con mucha responsabilidad.  

Hernan nació en la ciudad de Paucartambo en el departamento del Cusco y vive junto con su familia en esta hermosa ciudad, él tiene 30 años de edad y tiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene cuatro hijos a quienes saca adelante.
texts.en:
Hernan  is grateful to the Kiva lenders for this loan and he is happy about the assistance.  He continues selling lamb, beef, chicken, and pork.  He has been doing this work for several years and things have been going well for him, thanks to the effort he puts into his work.

Hernan continues to belong to the “Mamacha Carmen” communal bank and he needs this loan to buy lamp, pork, chicken, fish, and other things.  He is grateful and values this loan and is committed to making his monthly payments responsibly and on time.

Hernan was born in the city of Paucartambo, within the Cusco department and lives with his family in this beautiful city.  He is 30 years old, in a common law marriage, and has four children that he gets ahead.

loans.use: to buy meats.

loans.name: Marvin Antonio

texts.es:
El señor Marvin es una persona muy trabajadora y responsable vive en una comunidad al sur de Honduras junto a su familia. Su negocio es la compra y venta de ganado, desde hace 10 años, la cual funciona en su casa de habitación en el municipio donde vive y lugares cercanos a este.
Don Marvin necesita el préstamo para la compra de más vacas para seguir realizando su trabajo, el cual le ayuda mucho  en la economía de su hogar. Con el préstamo espera que sus ventas aumenten y que este le sirva de mucho ya que no cuenta con las reces necesarios para cubrir los pedidos solicitados por sus clientes más en estas épocas navideñas que sus clientes le encargan mucho producto.
 Don Marvin gracias a esta inversión espera poder mejorar la calidad de vida de la familia con el aumento de los ingresos en el hogar, espera en un corto plazo hacer crecer su negocio y  con esto poder seguir apoyando a su familia.


Choluteca, Honduras – Noviembre del  2013
texts.en:
Marvin is a hardworking and responsible person who lives with his family in a southern Honduras community.  He has been buying and selling livestock in his town and nearby for ten years out of his home.

Marvin needs a loan to buy more cattle to continue his work, which helps him very much financially.  He expects this loan to be very helpful to him, since he doesn’t have the cattle he needs to cover his orders, especially during these Christmas holidays when he gets many customer orders.

Marvin will be able to improve his family’s quality of life and increase his income with the help of this loan.  He expects his business to grow in a short time and continue to support his family.

Choluteca, Honduras – November 2013

loans.use: to buy cattle.

loans.name: James

texts.en: This is 25-year-old James.  He is married and has one child, aged three.  In 2008, James established his provisions, drinks, toiletries and water business. He started the business to be self-reliant after coming from the village.  His business is located in the city center and his main customers are adults. Working seven days a week and ten hours a day, he earns about Le 1,595,600 every month from this business. He would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000.  James requires a loan in order to buy provisions and toiletries. He hopes that this loan can increase the stock and expand the business. In the future, James plans and hopes to improve the business and expand the shop. He thanks you for your support

loans.use: to pay for provisions and toiletries.

loans.name: Precious

texts.en:
Precious is a 25-year-old young woman, married with one child. She lives in Nkayi, a district in central Zimbabwe. She is well-known in her community for volunteering at community centers and using her passion to help orphans and vulnerable children. 

Precious operates a dressmaking business sewing school uniforms and selling them to residents and schools in her community. She has been in the business for eleven months and employs one person. In addition to earning a livelihood, Precious also strives to create more employment in her community.

Precious will use the loan to purchase a sewing machine, thread, and fabric. This will enable her to produce more clothing and as a result improve her business. In turn, this will allow her to support her family members and put herself through school.

loans.use: to purchase fabric and a sewing machine for her business

loans.name: Rugiatu

texts.en:
This is 22-year-old Rugiatu. She is married and has two children, ages three and five. She has one additional dependent who lives with her to help with her education. 

In 2005, Rugiatu established her baby clothing business. She began her business to be self-reliant, after dropping out of school. Her business is located in city center and her main customers are women. Working seven days a week and ten hours a day, she earns about SLL 529,875 every month from this business. 

Rugiatu would like a loan in the amount of SLL 3,000,000. She requires a loan in order to add napkins, diapers, baby oil, and pampers to her stock. She hopes that this loan will help her to improve the stock and raise the profit. 

In the future, Rugiatu plans to expand the business to a shop. She started the business by selling for a sister, now she owns her own business. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to pay for napkins, diapers, baby oil, and pampers.

loans.name: Nasratu

texts.en:
Nasratu is thirty one years old.  She is married and has two children, who are five and twelve. She also supports one additional dependent, as she is helping her brother complete his education.

In 2009, Nasratu established her retail business. She sells chains, earrings, beads, bags, blouses, and cosmetics. Nasratu began her business because she wants to be self-reliant and contribute to the household income. Initially, when Nasratu started the business, she was hawking goods. Now, she owns a permanent stall. The business is located in the city center and women are her primary customers.  Nasratu works 7 days a week, 10 hours a day. She earns about SLL 970,200 every month from her business. 

Nasratu is requesting a loan of SLL 3,000,000 to buy merchandise for her business. She hopes that this loan will improve her stock and raise profits. In the future, Nasratu plans to expand her business into a shop. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase chains, earrings, bags, and blouses for her business

loans.name: Hermine

texts.en:
Hermine is married and has two children. She is from Yenoqavan village of Tavush region. Hermine works as a teacher at the village local school. Her salary, however, is so low, that she cannot afford a living based on that salary alone. 

Hermine is engaged in cattle and livestock breeding and in cultivation of wheat, grass, and several fruits such as plums, pomegranates, blood oranges, apples, pears, and walnuts. With the help of her husband she sells the agricultural products in the local market, which is a very important source of income for the family. 

To continue her agribusiness in a sustainable way, Hermine is requesting a loan for $1,000, which she will use to purchase five piglets and forage for cattle.

loans.use: to purchase five piglets and forage for cattle

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a 26-year-old single oman who lives in the town of Shurugwi, Zimbabwe. She is very passionate about empowering young women in her community to overcome the economic hardships that many of them face. She is currently running a poultry business. She started the business in 2012 and currently produces about 130 broiler birds every six weeks and sells them to the local residents in her village. 

The loan will enable her to improve her business considerably. She will purchase more broiler chicks and chick feed to increase production. An improvement in her business means that she will be able to  provide for her two dependents and put them through school.

loans.use: To purchase more chicks and feed

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene is 18 years old and lives in Matobo District, Zimbabwe. She is an aspiring entrepreneur running a hair autré (hair products shop) in order to become financially independent. She started this business when she was 17 years old after she finished her schooling. She acquired training and experience from working in her friend’s hair salon. She inspires young women in her community as both a community health trainer and an entrepreneur. She would like to move the business to a more central location and increase her clientele base.

The Kiva loan will enable her to open her own hair salon and purchase a hair dryer, rollers, ceramic iron or tongs and hair products needed in her salon. Her hope is to provide for her family and improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase more equipment and supplies for her hair products shop

loans.name: Getu

texts.en: Getu is married with three children who all go to school. She also takes care of additional her grandchildren. She has a business of selling produce and has been in this business for 10 years. She has applied for a loan of 200,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy tomatoes, sweet potatoes, cassava, green bananas and onions. She generates additional income from poultry farming. She moves door to door selling and sells to all categories of people seven days a week. Her business challenges include defaulters and seasonality. She is aspiring to get a permanent business premise and also to sell on a wholesale basis only.  She resides in the family house which has access to electricity but does not have access to piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy tomatoes, sweet potatoes, cassava, green bananas and onions.

loans.name: Ramatulai

texts.en: This is 35-year-old Ramatulai. She is single and has two children ages 15 and 10 years. In 2007, Ramatulai established her commercial business selling ladies' dresses, blouses, skirts, and so on. She began her business because she wanted to be self-sufficient and to provide for her children’s schooling and welfare. She opens her business seven days a week and 12 hours a day. She earns SLL 1,000,000 from this business every month. She would like a loan in the amount of SLL 5,000,000. Ramatulai requires a loan in order to buy ladies' blouses, dresses and skirts . She hopes that this loan will increase her profit margin by SLL 700,000. Ramatulai has not yet achieved her goal of opening a dressmaker store or fashion store but is still striving hard to achieve it. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy ladies blouses, dresses and skirts .

loans.name: Andre

texts.en:
Andre is 38 years hold and has six children between the ages of 2 and 16. He would like to use his Kiva loan to support labor costs and to buy fertilizer during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase crop production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Alphonse

texts.en:
Alphonse is 52 years old. He is requesting a loan, which he will use to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming, he hopes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Godwin

texts.en: Godwin is a young Tanzanian entrepreneur.  He operates various businesses within his community and is a big supporter of TAHUDE Foundation for implementation of renewable energy.  Godwin is determined to install five biodigesters within his community.  He is doing this for three reasons:  (i) he wants to be a role model in his community, (ii) for part of his overall business advertising, and (iii) for the sake of the 10% commission rate that TAHUDE pays him for each biodigester he installs.  TAHUDE Foundation is convinced that Godwin can handle this project with minimal supervision.  As such, he has applied for this loan.  We hope the success of Godwin’s initiative will reduce the community’s dependence on depleting firewood and trees, and will consequently halt deforestation.  Also, each biodigester installed will cut down the household expenses of the families, which makes this investment a wise decision.

loans.use: to purchase biodigesters/biogas for resale in his community

loans.name: Shukrani

texts.en: Shukrani runs a microcredit project in his local community.  He is highly inspired by the TAHUDE Foundation initiative of installing biogas systems in rural Tanzania.  Now, Shukrani wants to install five biodigesters to households that are able to pay him through his microcredit project.  TAHUDE Foundation is confident in Shukrani's performance based on his previous due diligence.  We hope the success of Shukrani’s initiative will reduce the community’s dependence on depleting firewood and trees, and will consequently help in environmental conservation.  Biodigesters will also provide organic fertilizer for the households which will install the system.

loans.use: to purchase biodigesters/biogas for resale in his community

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is a 37-year-old Tanzanian businessman.  He owns and strongly promotes a renewable energy business.  Standing with him in this picture is the TAHUDE Foundation Director (in white shirt).  

Charles, in partnership with TAHUDE Foundation, has decided to install ten biodigesters in his local community/village.  The customers are available and TAHUDE will pay Charles a commission rate of 10% for each biodigester that he installs.  This initiative will increase his social status in the community, promote his renewable energy business in the rural community, and generate income through the 10% commission from TAHUDE Foundation.  His initiative will reduce the community’s dependence on depleting firewood/trees and consequently halt deforestation.  Also, each biodigester installed will cut down on expenditures of the families which took the wise decision of such investment.

loans.use: to purchase biodigesters/biogas for resale in his community

loans.name: Lazaro

texts.en: Lazaro is a hard-working man who purely depends on agriculture and livestock keeping.  He is one of the people who are really facing many life challenges in rural Tanzania, but is determined to change his situation.  After observing the benefits that other people are getting by installing the biodigester, Lazaro has decided to invest in this technology as well.  He is requesting that TAHUDE Foundation provide this loan for a biodigester that will impact his life.  He will be able to pay back this loan within 12 months through his farm product sales, and the biodigester life span goes to 20 years!  Our support to Lazaro’s loan application will benefit his family and also his community at large (to reduce deforestation, reduce carbon dioxide emissions, avoid health problems associated with smoke, and save expenditures on “wood energy and kerosene”).

loans.use: to purchase a biodigester for personal use and also one for resale

loans.name: Silas

texts.en: Silas is a 35-years-old young Tanzanian whose family is dedicated to farming and livestock keeping.  He lives a relatively decent life compared to most of his neighbors.  Silas has learnt that these days many people are passing through tough times as their family expenditures increase.  As dairy and farming represents his community's primary source of income, he is constantly looking at ways to introduce new business that is both profitable and helpful to his community in reducing daily expenditures.  He has now decided to install biodigesters which allow the beneficiary families to reduce energy and fertilizer costs, as well as give better treatment to their animal waste.  Their cow manure will be processed by the digester into renewable methane-rich biogas and biofertilizer, allowing the reduction of dependence on costly and damaging kerosene and agrochemical fertilizers that degrade soils and contaminate groundwater.

loans.use: to purchase biodigesters/biogas for resale in his community

loans.name: Filemon

texts.en: Filemon, a dairy farmer in Tanzania, is constantly looking to reduce his operational costs on a daily basis.  His cows produce sufficient milk that would be suitable for starting a small yogurt and cheese business, but he cannot think of these ideas due to the high cost of energy required.  With the installation of biogas at his home and around his neighbors' circle, Filemon and his neighbors will be able to generate clean-burning, renewable biogas from the several kilograms of manure their cows produce weekly, allowing them to significantly decrease energy costs.  Moreover, they will use the fertilizer generated by the system on their animal feed – plants remaining - allowing them to save on agrochemical fertilizer costs.  This TAHUDE Foundation biodigester initiative has impressed Filemon so much that, in addition to his own biodigester, he has decided to build four more biodigesters for his neighbors under the agreement that they will pay him little by little under the supervision of TAHUDE Foundation Microcredit.  TAHUDE Foundation is grateful and appreciates his enthusiasm.  His success will impact not only his family and parents, but also the community at large.

loans.use: to purchase biodigesters/biogas for resale in his community

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia, a 54-year-old married woman from the town of Trinidad, Bohol, earns a living through her sari-sari or retail business as she sells various goods and items to the people in her community. Her husband works as a farmer.

Lilia is requesting a loan to buy more groceries to sell such as canned goods, candies, soda, soap, toiletries, biscuits and snack foods as well as fertilizer for the farm. With this, she will be able to improve the variety of her stocks and thus attract more buyers. Lilia hopes to make her business a sustainable success.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell such as canned goods, candies, soda, soap, toiletries, biscuits and snack foods, as well as fertilizer for the farm

loans.name: Noe Reinaldo

texts.es:
Noé, es parte de una familia compuesta por su compañera de vida y un hijo de 24 años de edad, se dedica al cultivo de granos básicos y hortalizas, realizando está actividad puede generar los ingresos necesarios para que en su hogar no falte nada.
 Comprará abono, fertilizantes, plaguicidas, y semillas, tanto para sembrar maíz como para cultivar tomate, pepino, y chiles. Espera tener una producción más grande, una cosecha de mayor calidad, cumplir con las exigencias de sus clientes, aumentar sus ventas y tener ingresos extras que necesita para cumplir con sus compromisos económicos.
Aspira a tener su casa propia para darle a su familia un lugar seguro.
texts.en:
Noé is part of a family made up of his life’s partner and 24 year old son.  He raises basic grains and vegetables and this generates the necessary income so that he is not in need of anything.

He will buy compost, fertilizer, pesticides, and seeds so he can plant corn, tomatoes, cucumbers, and peppers.  He expects to have a larger and better quality production, meet his customer demand, increase his sales, and have extra income that he needs to meet his financial obligations.

He wants to have a home of his own so he can provide a secure place for his family.

loans.use: to buy farming supplies.

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Although she has received no formal education, Esi is an entrepreneur. She specializes in selling fish, in Asafa (near Elmina). She has been involved in this enterprise for twelve years.

Esi is married and has three children. Her husband works as a fisherman. The proceeds from her business normally go toward helping her husband to cover the family’s general expenses and to pay their children’s school fees.

Esi will use the loan to purchase increased amounts of fish, which will help her to improve her overall sales. With the new profits from her expanded business, Esi plans to further diversify the types of products that she sells, adapting to changing customer preferences.

loans.use: to purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Teresa

texts.es:
Teresa continua dedicándose a la venta de ropa para caballeros, damas y niños, ella  sigue teniendo el pequeño puesto de venta en uno de los mercados de la ciudad de Paucartambo donde expende sus productos. Ya son varios años que se dedica a  este negocio y le va muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo, ella pertenece al banco comunal “Mamacha Carmen” y esta oportunidad requiere el préstamo para comprar ropa como por ejemplo chompas, pantalones, camisas para estas épocas de navideña y año nuevo. 

Ella nació en la ciudad de Accha pero ahora vive junto con su familia en la hermosa ciudad de Paucartambo en el departamento del Cusco, ella tiene 55 años de edad y es casada y fruto de esta relación tiene siete hijos a quienes saca adelante.
texts.en:
Teresa continues to sell clothing for men, women and children. She still has her small sales booth at one of the markets of the town of Paucartambo where she sells her products. She has been in this line of work for several years and thanks to her hard work, she does very well. She's a member of the "Mamacha Carmen" communal bank. On this occasion she requests the loan in order to purchase garments such as sweaters, pants and shirts for this Christmas and New Year's season.

She was born in the town of Accha, but she currently lives with her family in the charming town of Paucartambo, in the department of Cusco. She's 55 years old and married, and from this relationship she has seven children whom she gets ahead.

loans.use: to purchase garments such as sweaters, pants and shirts.

loans.name: Kadiatu

texts.en:
This is 43-year-old Kadiatu. She is married and has six children, ages 23, 21, 20, 17, 15, and 6 years old. 

In 1993, Kadiatu established her rice and stew, couscous, and fried rice with meat business. She began her business because she wanted to fight poverty and to be independent. She operates her business six days a week and ten hours a day. She earns SLL 1,500,000 (Sierra Leone leones) every month from this business. 

Kadiatu would like another loan, in the amount of SLL 3,000,000. She requires a loan in order to buy bags of rice, palm oil, and cooking oil. She hopes that this loan will help increase her profit by SLL 1,000,000. 

Kadiatu has now got the capacity to transform to a standard restaurant and she is now looking for a site that could be accessible to her customers. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy bags of rice, palm oil, and cooking oil.

loans.name: María Donata

texts.es:
María de 32 años de edad, estudio hasta 3 grado, ya que sus padres no quisieron que continuara estudiando, porque mencionaban que eso era algo, en que el tiempo se desaprovechaba. Tiene 4 hijos, quienes estudian y solamente ella cubre con toda la responsabilidad, ya que su esposo desgraciadamente falleció.

María inicio a  trabajar desde los 11 años, ya que acompañaba a sus hermanos mayores a hacer jornales y así aprendió a cortar caña. Ahora, trabaja como ama de casa, desde hace ocho años. Sin embargo, en la época de producción de caña de azúcar, María continua yendo a trabajar. Ademas, tiene una pequeña granja de pollos de engorde. Todo este sacrifico lo hace por sacar adelante a sus hijos, y que no les falta nada.

El préstamo sera utilizado, para invertirlo en el negocio de la avicultura, ya que necesita comprar mas pollitos, concentrado, vitaminas y ademas mejorar el equipo, por lo que adquiriría comederos y bebederos.

A María le gustaría construir su casa de un mejor material, ya que en la que habita, es de lamina y en el día la calor impide que puedan estar largo tiempo dentro de ella, y en la noche la temperatura baja y el frio es mucho mayor. Ademas, piensa trabajar mucho para sacar adelante a sus hijos y que la calidad de vida de ellos pueda mejorar en un futuro.
texts.en:
Maria, 32, left school after the third grade because her parents couldn't afford for her to go farther.  She has 4 children of her own now, all in school.  Maria's husband died, sadly, so she has sole responsibility for the children.  

Maria started working when she was only 11 years old, working day jobs cutting sugar cane with her older brothers and sisters.  She has worked as a house cleaner for the past eight years, but still cuts sugar cane for extra income.  She started a poultry business, as well, more work that she's willing to do because it provides another means to help her children get ahead in the world.

Maria will use this loan to pay for supplies--chicks, feed and vitamins, for example--and make improvements to the feeders and hatcheries where she keeps her chickens.

For the future, Maria would like to rebuild her house with better materials.  Her family lives in a metal shack now, one too hot to live in during the day and only tolerable at night when it's cooler.  She says that she plans to continue working hard in the hope that she can give her children a better future.

loans.use: to buy supplies for her poultry business.

loans.name: Aba

texts.en:
Aba is divorced and has three children. Even though she did not receive any formal education, Aba is a successful businesswoman. She sells fish, in Asafa (near Elmina). She has been actively involved in this business for about ten years.

As the sole breadwinner in the family, Aba uses her income to provide for the entire family. Aba will use the loan to purchase increased amounts of fish, which will help her to improve her overall sales. With the new profits from her expanded business, Aba plans to further diversify the types of products that she sells, adapting to changing customer preferences.

loans.use: to purchase increased amounts of fish to resell

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is a taxi driver in Asafa (near Elmina). He has had some formal education, and he is a middle school graduate. He is married and has five children. His wife is a trader. Charles has been working as a taxi driver for close to twenty-six years. His income is used to help his wife pay the utility bills and their children’s school fees.

He plans on using his loan to help him purchase his own taxi. This will free him from working for someone else. With his own taxi, he will be able to retain all of his profits, increasing his family’s standard of living.

loans.use: to purchase his own taxi, rather than continuing to work for someone else.

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en: Jennifer is divorced and has one child. After successfully graduating from middle school, Jennifer is now an established businesswoman. She sells secondhand clothing in Asafa (near Elmina). She has been actively involved in this business for about ten years. As the sole breadwinner in the family, Jennifer uses her income to provide for the entire family. Jennifer will use the loan to purchase increased amounts of secondhand clothing, thus helping her to improve her overall sales. With the new profits from her expanded business, Jennifer plans to diversify the type of products that she sells, hence adapting to changing customers preferences.

loans.use: to purchase increased amounts of secondhand clothing, thus aiding her to improve her overall sales.

loans.name: Tamemsu Manepeh Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Tamemsu Manepeh” group. They are small scale businesswomen based in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. With this loan, they will be able to expand their respective businesses, make more profit and consequently improve on their standard of living. 
The featured leader of this group is Kaday.  Kaday is age 51.  She was born in Tonkolili district, northern Sierra Leone. Currently, she is living in Magburaka town with her husband and six children. Her husband is a taxi driver and her children are attending primary and secondary schools. Kaday sells breads and has been selling breads for many years now. With her share of this loan, she is going to buy a larger quantity of bread to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to buy a larger quantity of bread to add to her current stock

loans.name: Aba

texts.en: Due to difficult circumstances Aba did not have access to any form of formal education, yet this has not stopped her from achieving her dream of becoming an entrepreneur. Currently, Aba sells fish in Asafa (near Elmina). She has been involved in this enterprise for over forty years. Aba is married to a farmer and has six children. The proceeds from her business normally go towards helping her husband pay their children’s school fees and their other expenses. Aba has identified that there are growing demands among consumers for her product. Nevertheless, she is unable to meet their needs due to limited inventory capacity. Thus she aims to use her loan to purchase more fish to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Aba wants to buck the trend by ensuring that all her children will be given the opportunity to further distance their family from poverty.

loans.use: to purchase more fish to sell.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en: Charles runs a small provisions stand in Asafa (near Elmina). He has had some formal education, as he is a junior high school graduate. He is married and has three children. His wife is a fishmonger. Charles has been working as a provisions seller for close to six years. His income is used to help his wife pay the utility bills and their children’s school fees. He plans on using his loan to purchase an increased quantity of provisions, thus allowing him to meet rising customer demands. He hopes to use the profits from his enterprise to develop his business further and ensure that all his children receive an education.

loans.use: to purchase an increased quantity of provisions, thus allowing him to meet rising customer demands.

loans.name: Tam-Tamnesu Group

texts.en: Mariama is the featured leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Mariama was born in Tonkolili district, in northern Sierra Leone, 36 years ago. She is married to a trader and the couple has four children: two in primary school and two in secondary school. For many years now, Mariama has been selling palm oil (the country’s most popular cooking oil), Maggi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), tomatoes, etc. With the help of this loan, Mariama and her group members will be able to expand their respective businesses, make more sales, and consequently improve their living conditions. Mariama will use her share of the loan (800,000 Sierra Leonean leones) to buy palm oil, Maggi, tomatoes, etc., in wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to buy palm oil, Maggi, tomatoes, etc., in wholesale to add to her current stock

loans.name: Isatu

texts.en:
This is 40-year-old Isatu. She is married and has three children, who are aged 20, 16 and 13 years. In 2008, Isatu established her groundnut business. She began her business, because she wanted to be gainfully employed by herself and meet her daily needs and wants. Working six days a week and 12 hours a day, she earns about SLL 2,000,000 every month from this business.

She would like a loan of SLL 4,500,000. Isatu requires a loan to buy more bags of groundnuts. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately SLL 1,000,000. Isatu has opened a special account for her children's welfare. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more bags of groundnuts.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Due to difficult circumstances Alice did not have access to any form of formal education, yet this has not stopped her from achieving her dream of becoming an entrepreneur. Currently, Alice sells fish in Asafa (near Elmina). She has been doing so for about 20 years. As a divorcee with two children, Alice uses all her income to feed and provide for her family. She will use the loan to purchase an increased amount of fish, which will aid her in improving her overall sales. Alice wants to use the future profits from her expanded business to ensure that all her children are able to receive an education.

loans.use: to purchase an increased amount of fish, which will aid her in improving her overall sales.

loans.name: Ricardo

texts.es: El señor Ricardo tiene la edad de 54 años, habita en el municipio de Juigalpa, labora para una institución del estado en un programa de mejoramiento de semilla, su familia la conforman su esposa y su hija de 13 añitos, ambas están estudiando preparándose para tener  un mejor futuro en la vida, estos gastos de estudios los cubre don Ricardo con su salario, ya que  actualmente solamente el labora. Está requiriendo este primer crédito para realizar repello de paredes, para mejorar la apariencia física de su vivienda, recurre a este préstamo para poder comprar los materiales como cemento, arena  y el pago de la mano de obra.
texts.en: Ricardo is 54 years old, lives in the town of Juigalpa and works for a state institution in a seed improvement program.  His family is made up of his wife and 13 year old daughter.  Both are attending school, preparing themselves for a better future.  Ricardo pays the cost of education through his salary, since he is the only one who works at the moment.  He needs this first loan so he can plaster his walls in order to improve the physical appearance of his house.  He is asking for this loan so he can buy supplies such as cement, sand, and pay for labor.

loans.use: to buy building supplies and pay for labor.

loans.name: Stand Alert Group

texts.en: Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT) is very pleases to present to you members of the Stand Alert group for the second time. This group of entrepreneurs has just finished repaying their last loan and is now requesting another loan for 800,000 Sierra Leonean Leones for each in the group. With the help of this  loan, they are again empowered to add more inventories into their respective business. Ibrahim, the leader of the group, will use his share of the loan to buy more medicines to add to his current stock of drugs to sell.

loans.use: to purchase drugs to add to his current stock

loans.name: Hajiratu

texts.en: Although she has received no prior formal education, Hajiratu is an entrepreneur. She specializes in selling plantains in Asafa (near Elmina). Hajiratu is married and has two children. Her husband works as a taxi driver. The proceeds from her business normally go towards helping her husband cover the family’s general expenses and pay their children’s school fees. Hajiratu wants to use her loan to increase her current inventory levels, hence allowing her to sell greater quantities of plantains. In the long term, Hajiratu plans to reinvest future profits into her business, thus helping her expand and meet the needs of rising customer demands.

loans.use: to increase her current inventory levels, hence allowing her to sell greater quantities of plantains.

loans.name: Jose Damian

texts.es:
Damián, está necesitando capital para invertir en la compra de dos terneros, para críalos y luego venderlos a sus clientes y de esa manera obtener los ingresos que necesita para seguir cubriendo los gastos familiares.
Con el préstamo anterior compro los insumos agrícolas necesarios para el cultivo de maíz y frijol, con lo que su cosecha fue muy abundante, brindo mejor calidad a sus clientes, sus ganancias aumentaron y las ha invertido en  los gastos familiares.
texts.en:
Damian needs capital to buy two bulls to raise and then resell to his customers.  In this way he can obtain the income he needs to continue covering his family expenses.

He used the money from the previous loan to buy farming supplies for his corn and bean crops.  His harvest was very abundant, he provided his customers with good quality, his earnings increased, and he used them to pay for his family expenses.

loans.use: to buy bulls.

loans.name: Héctor Javier

texts.es: Héctor, con 41 años de edad, es casado y padre de dos hijos adolescentes, a los cuales ha sacado adelante con el fruto de su trabajo como cerrajero. Esta actividad la realiza desde hace 26 años, aprendió de manera empírica y su taller está ubicado en el patio trasero de su vivienda, donde elabora productos bajo pedido como puertas, rejas, ventanas, entre otros; de esta forma genera los recursos suficientes para llevar el sustento a su hogar. Su empuje, perseverancia y dinamismo, le han permitido sobrepasar diversos obstáculos que la vida le presenta y, por ello se motiva a solicitar el apoyo del crédito, con el que desea comprar un soldador Lincon y materia prima al por mayor (acero, hierro, aluminio, entre otros), así podrá optimizar su labor y mejorar el tiempo de producción para entregar los pedidos oportunamente, pues su equipo de trabajo se encuentra deteriorado y en algunas ocasiones le retrasa la labor; adicionalmente tendrá el material disponible para cumplirle a sus clientes, mejorando los ingresos. Héctor manifiesta que su mayor anhelo es hacer crecer su negocio, fortalecerlo y generar oportunidades de empleo; así podrá garantizar un mejor bienestar y protección económica para sus hijos y esposa.
texts.en: Héctor, 41, and his wife have two teenage children.  He supports his family with his income from his metal-working business.  Héctor started metal-working 26 years ago, learning as he went along, and now makes gates, fences and other metal fixtures.  He operates the business from a space in his yard.  His drive, energy and perseverance have allowed him to overcome everything that life has thrown at him.  Héctor is applying for a loan that he will use to buy a Lincoln soldering iron and bulk supplies of the raw materials (iron, steel, aluminum, etc.) that he needs to continue his business.  His equipment is old and he wants to invest in new equipment so that he can work more efficiently and deliver orders faster.  The investment will also allow him to stock the raw materials that he needs to fill his customers' orders in a timely way.  Héctor says that his greatest hope is to grow and strengthen his business.  He would like to provide jobs for others and increase his own income so that he can better support his wife and children.

loans.use: to buy supplies for his metal shop.

loans.name: Reina De La Paz

texts.es:
Reina, es madre de un hijo de 14 años, vive junto a sus padres su hijo, para poder aportar en los gastos familiares se dedica a sembrar granos básicos (maíz y frijol), es una actividad que aprendió de sus padres y que lo hace personalmente desde los 14 años de edad lo hace con ayuda de mozos, su mayor ventaja es que no paga alquiler de del terreno.
Utilizara el préstamo para pagar mano de obra para la recolección de granos básicos, de 8 manzanas de cultivo de maíz y 8 de frijoles. Con lo que espera tener a tiempo la cosecha para trasladarla a su casa donde será distribuida a sus clientes y de esta manera podrá tener mejores ventas, sus ingresos aumentaran.
Sueña con mantener su negocio fortalecido y activo para seguir teniendo ganancias que le faciliten dar a su familia mejores condiciones de vida y ofrecer una oportunidad de superación a su hijo.
texts.en:
Reina is the mother of a 14 year old boy. She lives with her son and her parents. To be able to help with the household expenses she grows basic grains (corn and beans). She learned this activity from her parents and has been farming for herself since she was 14 with the help of workers. Her main advantage is that she does not have to pay rent for her land.

Reina will use the loan to pay labor to harvest the basic grains, 8 hectares of corn and 8 hectares of beans. What she harvests will be transported to her house where it will be distributed to her customers. This way she can have greater sales and her profits will increase. She dreams of keeping her farm strong and active in order to continue to have income which helps give her family better living conditions and offer her son a way to get ahead.

loans.use: to pay for labor to harvest her basic grains.

loans.name: Ntombikayise

texts.en:
Ntombikayise is 29 years old and lives in the town of Umzingwane, Zimbabwe. She is married with three children and volunteers at a community dormitory for girls who live too far from their high school to walk to school each day. She has been a community health trainer for six years and volunteers in schools disseminating health information. She is currently running a cattle farm. She sells cattle to local abattoirs and dairy milk to the Umzingwane community. The business has drastically changed her life and has enabled her to put one of her children through school.  

Ntombikayise  will use the Kiva loan to purchase cattle feed and increase her earnings on her dairy and beef sales. She hopes to raise enough money to continue educating her children, herself and to support her ten siblings.

loans.use: to purchase cattle feed.

loans.name: Reina Isabel

texts.es: Reina, tiene 44 años de edad, es casada, tiene dos hijos, vive en el municipio de Choloma, Cortés.  Tiene 3 años de dedicarse a la venta de ropa usada como blusas, pantalones, camisas, también cosméticos. Además elabora y vende tamales de maíz con carne. Solicita el segundo préstamo para surtir el negocio, el cual es por 10,000 Lempiras. Con este préstamo va comprar ropa usada como blusas, camisas, camisetas, vestidos, pantalones. Su meta es ampliar el negocio para poder obtener ganancias y mejorar su vivienda.
texts.en: Reina is 44 years old, married, and has two children.  She lives in the town of Choloma, Cortés and has been selling used clothing, such as blouses, pants, shirts, and cosmetics for three years.  She also makes and sells corn and beef.  She is asking for this loan of 10,000 Lempiras to stock her business.  She will use the money to buy shirts, dresses, and pants.  Her goal is to grow her business so she can increase her earnings and improve her home.

loans.use: to buy clothing for resale.

loans.name: Joana

texts.en: Due to difficult circumstances, Joana did not have access to any form of formal education, yet this has not stopped her from achieving her dream of becoming an entrepreneur. Currently, Joana runs a chop bar (a roadside food stand) in Asafa (near Elmina). She has had the chop bar for four years. She is married to a taxi driver and they have three children. Joana uses all of her income to feed and provide for her family. Joana will use the loan to purchase additional ingredients to increase her serving capacity. Joana wants to use the future profits from her expanded business to ensure that all of her children are able to receive an education.

loans.use: to purchase additional ingredients to increase her serving capacity.

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en: Even though Adwoa grew up in poverty without an education, she has fulfilled her dream of achieving a better life for her and her family. Currently, Adwoa is an entrepreneur. She sells smoked fish in Asafa (near Elmina). Her business enterprise has grown substantially since she began over one year ago. Adwoa is married and has six children. Her husband works as a farmer. The proceeds from her business normally go towards helping her husband cover the family’s general expenses and pay their children’s school fees. Adwoa wants to use her loan to increase her current inventory levels so that she can sell greater quantities of smoked fish. In the long term, Adwoa plans to reinvest future profits into her business, thus helping her expand and meet the needs of rising customer demands.

loans.use: to increase her current inventory levels so that she can sell greater quantities of smoked fish.

loans.name: Araba

texts.en: Due to difficult circumstances, Araba did not have access to a formal education, yet this has not stopped her from achieving her dream of becoming an entrepreneur. Currently, Araba sells charcoal in Asafa (near Elmina). She has been involved in this enterprise for four years. Araba is married to a farmer and has four children. The proceeds from her business help her husband to pay their children’s school fees. Araba has identified that there are growing demands among consumers for her product. Nevertheless she is unable to meet their needs due to limited inventory. She aims to use her loan to purchase more charcoal to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Araba wants to ensure that all her children will be given the opportunity to further distance their family from poverty.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Bernice

texts.en: Even though Bernice grew up in poverty without an education, this has not stopped her from fulfilling her dream of achieving a better life for her and her family. Currently, Bernice is an entrepreneur. She sells kenkey and cooking utensils in Asafa (near Elmina). Her business enterprise has grown substantially since she began 10 years ago. Bernice is married and has three children. Her husband works as a mason. The proceeds from her business normally go towards helping her husband cover the family’s general expenses and pay their children’s school fees. Bernice wants to use her loan to increase her current inventory levels, hence allowing her to sell greater quantities of kenkey and cooking utensils. In the long term, Bernice plans to reinvest future profits into her business, thus helping her expand and meet the needs of rising customer demands.

loans.use: to increase her current inventory levels, hence allowing her to sell greater quantities of kenkey and cooking utensils.

loans.name: Maria Vicenta

texts.es:
